executive_summary: The Fabric, Craft and Sewing Supplies industry has been navigating a transforming landscape marked by evolving consumer preferences and technological advancements. Recently, there's been a notable upswing in interest in DIY projects, which has been instrumental in maintaining consumer engagement. Shoppers increasingly seek personalized and unique items, driving them to craft their own products. This trend has provided an essential buffer against the broader challenges of the retail sector.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the past five years, discount department stores and other large retailers have been attracting a large number of crafting consumers, pressuring industry sales. Many consumers shop at other retail outlets for their fabric and craft needs, such as big-box retailers and discount stores, which offer low prices and the convenience of one-stop shopping. Walmart is one of the industry's greatest external threats because the retail giant can offer large volumes of industry products at extremely low prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Inexpensive Imported Apparel Leads to a Drop in Homemade Clothing
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A boost in the import penetration of inexpensive apparel and the expansion of affordable off-the-rack clothing has led to a steep drop in the popularity of homemade clothing over the past few decades. As a result, most fabrics sold

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: E-COMMERCE AND DIGITAL ENGAGEMENT TRANSFORM TRADITIONAL FABRIC, CRAFT AND SEWING SUPPLY STORES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The expansion of e-commerce has significantly impacted traditional brick-and-mortar fabric, craft, and sewing supply stores. More consumers are shopping online for the convenience of having products delivered directly to their doorsteps and the advantage of accessing a broader product range than typically available in physical stores. Fabric, craft and sewing supply stores enhance their online presence with user-friendly websites, secure payments, real-time inventory updates and digital marketing strategies, including social media, to stay competitive and attract customers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: External competition from big-box retail outlets is expected to continue. These retailers have won customers over by offering lower prices for the same or comparable products. To stay competitive, fabric, craft and sewing supplies stores must either cut prices, which pressures profit, or offer unique products and services to attract customers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DIY Culture Will Fuel Industry Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The boom of DIY projects and handmade items will spark increased supply demand. Millennials and Gen Z will be at the forefront, seeking personalized and sustainable products. Influencer marketing and tutorials on platforms like YouTube and Pinterest will boost this trend as more people take up crafting as a hobby or side business.

Despite online growth, many shoppers still value the hands-on experience of buying craft supplies in person. Workshops, classes and store crafting events will enhance customer engagement and loyalty. Brick-and-mortar stores will diversify their offerings, blending retail space with creative hubs to attract clientele who appreciate the interactive and community aspects of crafting.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry primarily retail sewing and craft supplies, fabrics, patterns, yarns, needlework accessories, seasonal decorations and sewing machines. Stores that sell sewing machines with other household appliances are excluded from this industry.

positive_impact_factors: However, the industry has the advantage of direct contact with its customers, considering consumers often prefer to touch a fabric and feel its texture before purchasing it.

key_trends: Price, product offering and customer service are key strategies for stores to differentiate themselves. The size of the store affects which strategy will be successful.

Online operations boost external competition. The surge in e-commerce shopping habits is gradually diverting key customers from traditional stores, consequently sharpening the competitive edge of online-only businesses.

External competition has pressured growth. Large retailers and e-commerce platforms have drawn customers away from traditional fabric and craft stores by offering low prices, greater convenience and wider product selections.

DIY trends will fuel industry growth. Millennials and Gen Z, attracted to personalized and sustainable products, alongside influencer marketing and online tutorials, will significantly boost interest in crafting as a hobby or side business.
Michael's, Jo-Ann and Hobby Lobby dominate the industry. These larger stores have captured a significant market share because they benefit from economies of scale and brand recognition.
Smaller companies must offer niche products or specialized services to compete with the larger stores.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment comprises all women under the age of 25 and represents the most prominent market segment. Over the past five years, this demographic has experienced significant growth, driven by the increasing popularity of unique and customized clothing and accessories. Consumers in this segment have been traditionally sensitive to changes in fashion; an increasing number of women have participated in do-it-yourself (DIY) creations of clothes and accessories.

This segment includes women between the ages of 25 and 44. Consumers in this category purchase industry products for leisure activities, but may also make purchases for their children's craft projects and costumes for Halloween and school plays.

This segment includes women between the ages of 45 and 64. Many women within this group partake in such activities for leisure; finished goods are often given as gifts or used as home decorations. Their unwavering commitment to their craft enhances repeat business and word-of-mouth marketing, leading to a stable customer base and revenue levels that have remained consistent over the past five years.

This segment encompasses women aged 65 and above, a demographic with considerable leisure time for hobbies and recreational activities. Many women within this age group use industry products to create gifts and apparel for their younger family members. Classes and community events are highly appealing to women aged 65 and older, significantly enhancing foot traffic and fostering loyalty in fabric, craft, and sewing supplies stores. These initiatives cultivate lasting customer relationships.

This market includes male consumers who engage in specialized crafting and DIY sewing projects. Men often invest in high-quality fabrics and tools for activities like upholstery, leatherwork and garment making, which can involve significant expenditure. Highlighting functional and creative aspects, such as custom furniture and unique clothing projects, has effectively attracted and retained male customers.

products_and_services.product_description: FABRICS ACCOUNT FOR THE MAJORITY OF INDUSTRY REVENUE. This segment encompasses a variety of materials, including cotton, satin, silk and corduroy, which are extensively used for apparel construction, home decor and quilting projects, catering to diverse creative and functional applications. Fabrics' revenue share has been bolstered by a growing trend in do-it-yourself (DIY) fashion. An increasing number of consumers are engaging in projects to create their own clothing and household decor items.

A per capita disposable income boost has further added to the continued popularity of the segment's products. With more discretionary income to spend on hobbies and recreational activities, consumers have been slightly more drawn to crafting activities and have increased demand for this segment's products. This segment encompasses sewing patterns, seasonal decorations and various other miscellaneous products. The popularity of these items often fluctuates depending on the time of year, leading to variable sales patterns for specific products. The trend toward DIY projects has significantly boosted demand for patterned industry products. Individuals seek unique materials and designs to personalize their homes and workplaces, contributing to a burgeoning market for custom and specialized supplies.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Since fabric, craft and sewing supplies are typically purchased for leisure and hobby purposes, demand depends on consumers' ability to spend on nonessential goods. Therefore, a rise in per capita disposable income increases consumers' propensity to purchase more industry products, leading to increased demand and revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region boasts the largest number of fabric, craft and sewing supply stores. This area also contains the highest percentage of the US population, thereby expanding the potential customer base for these establishments. Florida is the largest state per establishment in the region and is well-known for its significant population of retired residents. This demographic characteristic makes Florida attractive to industry operators, as retirees often have more time to engage in hobbies and crafts.

The Western region ranks as the second-largest in terms of establishment, reflecting its substantial share of the US population. California, the most populous state in the West, boasts a higher-than-average household income, which attracts retail businesses to the area. Recognized as a major fashion hub in the United States, Los Angeles offers a strategic location for operators in the Fabric, Craft and Sewing Supplies industry. The industry products can be utilized in apparel manufacturing, fostering significant opportunities within the fashion sector.

The Great Lakes region is centrally located, providing easy access to distribution channels and major metropolitan areas. This makes it simpler for stores to manage logistics and efficiently reach a wide customer base. The region boasts a strong tradition of arts and crafts, fostering a community that values and participates in DIY projects. This cultural backdrop creates a robust fabric, craft and sewing supply market, ensuring a steady and enthusiastic customer base.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act of 2008 (CPSIA) protects children by banning products with unsafe lead and phthalate levels, ensuring compliance with federal standards. It mandates retailers to test all products for children under 12, including fabrics, buttons and craft kits. Violations incur criminal and civil charges, with fines of up to $100,000 per violation and prison sentences of up to five years.

The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) details the federal minimum wage, currently set at $7.25 per hour. Some states have additional minimum wage laws. FLSA also regulates businesses employing children under 18, mandating extensive child labor laws. These regulations cover minors' wages, work hours and permissible tasks. Child labor laws may vary by state, ensuring localized compliance and protections.

OSHA mandates that employers prominently display the OSHA workers' rights poster in an easily accessible location for all employees. OSHA safety regulations are industry-specific and vary based on each establishment's nature. Adhering to these safety standards is crucial for businesses, including fabric, craft and sewing supplies stores, to ensure a secure work environment and protect employees' well-being.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large stores have a competitive advantage
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large stores have a competitive advantage. Economies of scale allow large stores to benefit from vertical integration and generate higher returns. Brand recognition also benefits large stores by encouraging repeat customers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small stores compete by offering specialization
concentration_points.concentration_description: Smaller stores are generally independently owned, cater to a specific geographic market and are likely to specialize in niche fabrics, crafts or sewing supplies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the largest cost for the industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases vary significantly among retailers of different sizes. Over the past five years, the portion of fabric, craft and sewing supplies sourced from low-cost overseas producers has increased significantly to limit purchase costs. This segment includes purchasing inventory from manufacturers and wholesalers. To boost profitability, store owners must negotiate favorable pricing while maintaining a strong supplier relationship.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Shifts in e-commerce impact brick-and-mortar stores' profitability
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit varies depending on the size of the store, with larger establishments often achieving higher profit because of economies of scale and more efficient operational capabilities, which can lead to greater financial performance and competitiveness in the market.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Fabric, craft and sewing supplies stores are labor intensive and must provide excellent customer service and hire knowledgeable employees.

STORES USE CUSTOM MOBILE APPS TO OFFER REWARDS AND PERSONALIZED SHOPPING EXPERIENCES. Fabric, craft and sewing supply stores are adopting custom mobile apps featuring reward systems and personalized offers. These apps entice frequent shoppers with exclusive discounts and promotions, incentivizing them to return. Innovative mobile apps provide an accessible and user-friendly platform for customers to access discounts and membership information and help stores differentiate themselves in a competitive market.

Online shopping boost offers consumers more choices and often lower prices, drawing sales away from brick-and-mortar stores. With digital giants like Amazon and specialized online retailers becoming increasingly popular, traditional stores face a significant challenge in retaining their customer base. Online platforms frequently engage in aggressive discounting, making it tough for traditional stores to compete and maintain steady revenue streams. E-commerce sites can reduce overhead costs significantly, thus affording them the flexibility to offer lower prices.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: REVOLUTIONARY IN-STORE CRAFTING SPACES TRANSFORM FABRIC AND SEWING SUPPLY STORES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Some fabric, craft and sewing supply stores have started incorporating in-store crafting spaces where customers can access tools and equipment to work on their projects. These communal spaces serve as hubs for creativity and collaboration, enabling customers to share ideas, techniques and inspiration. Also, they provide opportunities for customers to test and use products before purchasing.

FAQs.question: Do your company's sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for sewing and craft materials will generally follow movements in per capita disposable income and available leisure time. In tough economic times, consumers struggle to justify discretionary purchases.

FAQs.question: Does your company retail a specific product segment or a wide array of products?
FAQs.answer: Retailers specializing in a single product may have a competitive edge, boosting sales volumes. Diversified retailers will be subject to less revenue volatility.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key end markets?
FAQs.answer: Retailers located in proximity to end markets will exhibit higher demand. Retailers situated near upstream suppliers will exhibit lower transportation costs, supporting increased profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Retailers entering long-term supply contracts can protect themselves from future input price volatility. Input price volatility makes forward-looking supply chain management highly difficult.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs by adopting technology?
FAQs.answer: Most retailers rely on labor to add a personal touch to their storefronts. There is limited opportunity to replace skilled and knowledgeable employees. Automation of bookkeeping and administrative tasks can reduce labor costs, boosting profitability.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging technologies like POS systems?
FAQs.answer: By using electronic point of sale and inventory management systems, retailers can reduce labor costs and free up employees to perform other tasks. Retailers using the most recent technology will exhibit higher operational efficiencies and larger profits.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Noncompliant retailers selling illegal or unsafe products will be subject to fines and penalties, hurting profitability. Compliant retailers, retailing environmentally friendly and approved products may be preferred by consumers, boosting sales volumes.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and occupational safety standards are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant retailers may have a competitive edge through an established reputation, boosting sales. Noncompliant retailers will be subject to fines, penalties and increased insurance premiums, diminishing profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Retailers that can use effective cost-cutting measures will exhibit higher operational efficiency and profitability. Retailers that engage in long-term supply contracts will have reduced purchase costs and wider profit.

FAQs.question: How does your inventory turnover compare to that of your competition?
FAQs.answer: Retailers that can minimize unsold inventory will have lower purchase costs and higher profitability. Retailers with high inventory turnover will be better positioned to engage in supply chain management, further reducing purchase costs.

FAQs.question: What measures do you take to achieve better customer loyalty? How can you cater to customers looking for DIY projects?
FAQs.answer: Companies benefit from developing customer relationships because of the growing competition and consolidation within the industry. For example, DIY seminars and crafting classes have been implemented to improve customer loyalty.

FAQs.question: Where is your business located? Do your locations experience heavy traffic? How do you attract repeat customers?
FAQs.answer: Companies should aim to locate their businesses on main roads or in high-traffic areas to maximize their visibility to consumers. By putting up signs and offering special discounts to loyal customers, clients may return to the operator.

FAQs.question: How do you hire workers? What is the training process for new hires? How much prior experience is necessary for workers at your business?
FAQs.answer: Companies require sales personnel with a broad knowledge of fabrics and sewing materials to provide good customer service and build loyalty. Generally, workers are hired through job postings as they require a particular skillset or through referral.

FAQs.question: How has the development of online shopping affected your business? Do you monitor trends in online shopping?
FAQs.answer: The development and penetration of online shopping have been decimating demand for traditional bricks-and-mortar stores. Operators have increased their online presence to stay relevant.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the Consumer Confidence Index? How significantly does consumer confidence impact product demand?
FAQs.answer: The Consumer Confidence Index measures the level of consumer optimism about economic conditions, like unemployment, growth and inflation. A boost in the consumer confidence index increases spending power, which increases product demand.

FAQs.question: How closely do you track trends in per capita disposable income? Does your overall performance fluctuate in line with general economic conditions?
FAQs.answer: Since fabric, craft and sewing supplies are typically purchased for leisure and hobby purposes, demand depends on consumers' ability to spend on nonessential goods. When per capita disposable income increases, overall sales also boost.
